modules.description: Implements a discrete event simulation loop that advances time in fixed steps. Accepts a time step and a function representing the simulation logic, then repeatedly executes the logic at each time step. Useful for modeling systems that evolve in discrete intervals, such as digital circuits or turn-based simulations.

This module implements simulation execution and validation routines. It processes homogeneous simulations of unit and boolean types, advancing their state with `go` and verifying expected outcomes at specific steps using `check`. Concrete use cases include testing circuit behavior over time and validating signal propagation correctness in digital logic simulations.

This module enables the creation and management of input widgets for boolean, integer, float, and signal values, organized into hierarchical layouts using horizontal/vertical boxes or frames. It supports extracting current values from these widgets and integrates with window management operations like dynamic resizing, value retrieval from windowed interfaces, and initializing windows with predefined input configurations. These capabilities are particularly useful for building responsive graphical interfaces where structured user input and adaptive UI composition are required.

This module defines types and functions for creating and updating graphical plots with signals like points, piecewise, and linear interpolation. It works with signals, scopes, and windows to visualize time-series data, supporting operations to update values and render plots at specific intervals. Concrete use cases include real-time plotting of sensor data or simulation outputs with precise control over display behavior.

This module defines signal generation and visualization operations for plotting, including piecewise, square, and linear waveforms, as well as point-based signals. It works with floating-point values, string labels, and Gtkplot.scope structures to create multi-channel visualizations. Concrete use cases include rendering 2D plots with labeled signals, setting up multi-pane windows with fixed or dynamic ranges, and composing complex plots with multiple synchronized scopes.

This module executes and validates simulations for unit and boolean types, providing `go` to advance simulation states and `check` to verify outcomes at specific steps. It directly supports modeling and testing digital circuits by simulating behavior over time and ensuring signal propagation correctness. Use cases include verifying sequential logic and testing timing-dependent circuit behavior.
